body:
@antinucleon 
![screenshot from 2016-07-11 13 48 01](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7245472/16746209/2897eb34-476e-11e6-943c-0cada1d62cad.png)
In practice, I can't see any difference. The parameter `magnitude` is needed to be tuned at training. Both Xavier and Kaiming don't grantee the network will converge.
weights from gpus will be averaged on cpu here. Could be that your network is very big and/or cpu is very slow

And I also notice that the training results of `mx.module.BucketingModule` and `FeedForward` are not the same. Using the same parameters, `FeedForward` can give a decreasing loss, while `BucketingModule` cannot, it seems the loss doesn't decrease for `BucketingModule`
I think that you will need to explicitly cast them.
@Godricly I will look into it again early next week.
@rfcv not yet, but it works pretty well on ubuntu.

I can confirm that it works fine on Windows and R on the latest version
with CUDA 7.5

@juanlp can't make sure what made my problem, what is your GPU environment?
@sxjscience 非常感谢，我确定是[#1228](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1228)这个问题。我把版本换成 20160223这个版本，mxnet可以正常工作

@5urprise @jimxinbo @horserma  I have the same problem and I agree that there is something wrong with `heads`. I change `heads` by creating a list containing indices of nodes with `data` or `label` in `nodel['name']`. This might be a quick and dirty way to get things work. I hope the DLMC members can give some hint on this problem. @tqchen @piiswrong

The same issue with #2672 

I agree with @geraint0923 . Downgrading should help.

I have tried to roll back the dmlc-core version 
from 25e80e916b8bb42e2f027ce352970904389ba76b 
to  67259fa8c600c04c9e1d067012ece7fdeb87158e
and the problem was solved.

@tqchen @piiswrong 
I found the one that caused problem. "0ad34c9" is the one we are looking for. The previous commit "1bf1337" is normal. One thing worth noting that this issue only happends when CuDNN is used. Since "0ad34c9" is something about CuDNN, I suspect there is somehow a connection between these. Hope you could figure out what the problem is. Thanks.
oh, could it be related to the tuner @piiswrong ?
@tqchen
@piiswrong can you confirm this on your machine?
looks like you have to bind them to the same ndarray with sym.bind
works fine for me. Seems like a gcc 5.0 specific issue

I found it did cost much when save params to model.
I don't think my network is big.There are only 3 full connected networks,about one hundred thousand params.And there are 24 cores in my machine,maybe cpu is not issue?
Could it be the network issue?How can I debug it? Sometimes it take 20 minutes to save model,so confused
@piiswrong
Try training on a single machine with epoch size set to a small number so it goes to saving quickly. Then add print to code and see which line is taking most time

Ok,i test it right now.
By the way,i have one question.
Which model should I choose when run multiple-machine mode.Why it need to generate its model in every node?In lr,or xgboost,the model is generated only on master.Could you help to explain it?
@piiswrong

Please check with this commit: https://github.com/taoari/mxnet/commit/0ab60ee8089d5244c275ba28559dd5e5eb4e8d7b

The reason is that multiprocessing does not work on Windows. The above commit is a bit outdated. You can make the changes on the latest version with following pattern.

```
if args.num_thread == 1:
    import Queue # move the except block here
    ...
else:
    import multiprocessing
    ... # move the try block here
```
Yes. Softmax is depreciated.
@starimpact  Seems to be caused by https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/cudnn_convolution-inl.h#L137 . Here `out.dptr_` should be `out_ptr`.
@tylorhxw I got the same problem when running the script run-mnist-example.sh. Could you please tell me how can I activate the MXNET_USE_DIST_KVSTORE  flag with this sh script? or in any other way?
Could you make sure you're using the latest version for both mxnet and its submodules?
Do you mean that you are trying to run dist training in one process?
@javelinjs I have the commit 97fa49f5767421bbc717d61f40c6bdfd3c601872 which is from the 3rd of July

if the code has problem, it should not be published.
I found the earlier released code which is a version of May can be used well in my project, but the newest one can not work at all.
I will not update my version to the newest mxnet in the future.
@starimpact Could you help test if the fix above works?
@sxjscience this problem I have fixed a few hours ago, but it comes another compilation failure problem. So I give up this newest version and used a version a few months ago.

@starimpact Yes, we need to be more careful in checking compatibility issues (We have not checked the new conv layer in old versions of CuDNN, which causes the previous problem). For compilation failure, a possible cause is that the submodules, e.g, MShadow, are not updated. You can put the failure information here if that still doesn't work.
@piiswrong  I am using gcc 4.8.

Anybody implemented triplet loss in MXNET? it is required when reproduce google facenet.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1503.03832
You can use softmaxoutput for this. Multiple outputs are summed during backward
@tqchen I can confirm the error and it was introduced by 25e80e916b8bb42e2f027ce352970904389ba76b
should be fixed by https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2679
should be fixed by https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2679

The general idea of execution engine is to eliminate the need of multi threaded programming.. So it is in general not adviced to issue commands from multiple threads. It would be great if you can be more specific on your usecase

Hello,

Thank you for the response! However, I am still a bit confused.

My aimed objective function is : softmax loss + custom value computed on internal fc layer

SoftmaxOutput does not output the raw loss value, so I cannot add this to another custom value and run MakeLoss on that? Or are you saying I don't need to explicitly add these symbols together

You don't need makeloss for simple addition between objectives. Use mx.sym.Group and they are implicitly added during backprop.
You just need to compute metric correctly for logging
You can use any one. They shouldn't differ by a lot.
It's fixed. Thanks

It works fine when I use the version in May.
It seems that your recent versions have many problems. compile failed, multiple threads problem, strange output "bulk exception problem..", bla.. bla...

The best way to proceed is to solve the problems :) The compilation error has already been fixed. It would be great if you can describe in more detail  what the problem is, or provide a script to reproduce the problem, so we can understand what is going on. Thanks

Thanks for helping us looking into it @ascust !

It is highly likely due to recently introduced auto tuner, that automatically tunes the CuDNN kernels every time a graph get executed, Since in your case you get a new graph each time, the tuner runs again. I think the tuner can be optionally turned of. It is also likely to be fine if you cache your reshaped executor.

In the future, this makes a good reason for tuner to store the previously tuned results @piiswrong
Yes, you are right. :)
@jonasrla Any updates on this PR? The test system should work fine now

Is your training iter the same as testing iter?
If so, this bug should have been fixed with the latest master

memonger is not activated by default. You need to call it explicitly.
1. This is due to preloading. I think there is a parameter you can tune to use less memory @tqchen
plot_network returns an graph object. You can call .view() on it to see the graph
If you want the model to output intermediate results. You can use mx.sym.Group to group it with the final output
This is likely due to your cudnn version being too old. Any reason you can't update to a newer one?
Thanks for the quick response. I'll try!

@piiswrong 谢谢回复！ 

   是的，我显式调用了mxnet-memonger ，使用如下代码：
    ......
    import memonger
    ......
    dshape = (args.batch_size, 3, 200, 200)
    net_mem_planned = memonger.search_plan(network, data=dshape)
    old_cost = memonger.get_cost(network, data=dshape)
    new_cost = memonger.get_cost(net_mem_planned, data=dshape)

```
然后我训练使用的是 ：
model = mx.model.FeedForward(
ctx                = devs,
symbol             = net_mem_planned,
num_epoch          = args.num_epochs,
learning_rate      = args.lr,
momentum           = 0.9,
wd                 = 0.00001,
initializer        = mx.init.Xavier(factor_type="in", magnitude=2.34),
**model_args
)
训练之前有如下打印
Search threshold=0 MB, cost=744 MB
Search threshold=0 MB, cost=744 MB
Search threshold=0 MB, cost=744 MB
但实际使用内存是，5G

另外，mxnet是吧rec一次加载进入内存的么？可以分片处理么？
```
@tqchen

My cudnn is v3. 
but 70fe57579 can compile ok. 
It is not a good idea to update some libraries frequently in a Project.

a.view()

check this issue #2087.
The memory returned by get_cost only considers part of actual cost.
there was a 7.0 release

sequence data samples have different lengths, thus require different network for each sample.
Bucketing is the process of sending samples to networks with corresponding lengths.
BYW, I get rid of the embedding layer as defined in the lstm.py and put my X_train directly to hidden layer. Is this why it is not working?
@piiswrong I put the dot.exe to the python directory.My python directory is D:\Anaconda. then I resolution this problem
@Godricly  thanks !

@piiswrong Thank you first. I get this idea about it. Can I directly apply the bucket_io.py to my Question-Anwser system? Or I need implement my own DataIter? Because I can just understand the code in it partially. And Do you have some detailed tutials about how to build our own bucket? Thanks a lot.

@thirdwing Could you please just give little more information about swig. Thanks!
Also, I would like to run the below code in java/scala, is there any way of accomplishing it.
`model = mx.model.FeedForward(ctx=mx.cpu(), symbol=SymbolFile,
            arg_params=AllParams, aux_params={}, num_epoch=1,
            learning_rate=0.05, momentum=0.9, wd=0.0001)`

---

Okay! What I think would work for me are the lines below, which are implemented in scala:

`val model = new FeedForward(
        modelDef, ctx, numEpoch, epochSize,
        optimizer, initializer, batchSize,
        argParams, auxParams, allowExtraParams, beginEpoch)`
Check if [this](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/rnn/bucket_io.py#L179-L180) help.
Is your provided_data empty?
@antinucleon The fact is this is a three line addition of a convenience method that is more (theoretically) correct than the standard. I don't feel like I should have to fight this hard for it.
try mx.module.bucketingmodel

Thanks very much for the quick reply.
I didn't know about mx.module. By reading through the code, it looks like BucketingModule allows one to use multiple bucket key, each of which is associated with an executor. Does it mean that if I want to use it for prediction on a generic DataBatch, I would need to create one executor per batch size (and copy weight matrices to each of them)?
Weight matrices are shared. So are internel buffers

@Godricly Thanks for your reply! I am pretty sure that X_train and y_train are not empty. I did print their shape right before build this **train_iter = mx.io.NDArrayIter(X_train, y_train, batch_size=batch_size)**.

Thank you, I will give that a try.
On the other hand, I was wondering if the requirement to binding a symbol can be relaxed a bit so that it allows an executor to take inputs with shapes that are only different on their first dimension (batch size)? I feel that this is natural as most of the execution is shared after all.
I find an example https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/autoencoder/solver.py, thanks
Thanks for the prompt response. This solves the problem.
What I'm asking is not the actual data, but the provided_data and provided_label attributes. They are used in LSTM to infer network shape. Go checking them in your your DataIter and the DataBatch.
@precedenceguo

```
>>> import numpy as np
>>> a = np.zeros((5,))
>>> a
array([ 0.,  0.,  0.,  0.,  0.])
>>> a[0:0]
array([], dtype=float64)
>>> 
```
It doesn't matter which dim is different. The memory buffer size will be different in the end. That's why you need to bind again.

@Yang507  I have meet a same problem with u, when I use captcha.gennerate() method, it occurs a same problem, TypeError: must be sequence of length 4, not 2. How do u do to solve this problem?

@tqchen Hi, Tianqi, Thanks a lot for your answer! 

Suppose I want to change [[1,2,3],[4,5,6]] to [[1,2,3],[10,5,6]], am I supposed to do like this:
a = mx.nd.array([[1,2,3],[4,5,6]])
a_line = mx.ndarray.slice_axis(a,axis=0,begin=1,end=2)   //get the second line of a
a_line = a_line.T     //transpose
a_line[0:1] = 10     // change the element value
a_line = a_line.T   //transpose back
a_other_line = mx.ndarray.slice_axis(a,axis=0,begin=0,end=1)   //get other lines
b = mx.ndarray.concatenate([a_other_line,a_line],False)   //concatenate

Are there more succinct solutions please? Thanks!
@sinmaystar you could input follow commands in your terminal:sudo pip install -U Pillow,then run lstm_ocr.py again, I almost forget it.
@Yang507  just update Pillow package is alright? my pillow version is 2.3.0, what's your pillow package version?
seems momentum = 0 means do not use momentum.
